—The member for Cowper will come to his question.

interjection.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Members on my left will come to order. The member for Cowper has the call and will proceed directly to his question.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker, I certainly will, but I am obliged to tell the truth. Could the minister advise the House of the outcomes of the recent APEC trade ministers' meeting in New Zealand, including APEC's continuing role in pressing for trade and economic reform in the Asia-Pacific region?

—I thank the member for Cowper for his timely question. The APEC meeting has just finished in Auckland this day. I was privileged to attend on behalf of the Australian government not only at Auckland but also at Christchurch where we had a very successful joint lamb rally and public meeting—with my counterpart and with the farm leader, Ian Donges, and his counterpart, Malcolm Bailey—which added weight to our case to persuade the US not to proceed down the path of barriers against our legitimate lamb exports.

answer.para: On APEC, I am delighted that further steps were taken to lock in the launch of a WTO millennium round at the Seattle ministerial scheduled for November of this year. In addition to agriculture and services which are part of the built-in agenda, there was a very clear-cut decision to add industrials to that in a way which was unanimously adopted by APEC trade ministers—a very pleasant change from some of our difficulties in recent times.

On the APEC only activity, the individual action plans are back in business. They are the engine room of APEC. A number of steps were taken to further build momentum with those individual action plans as well as practical proposals, such as the APEC food system, which is seeing a boost to two-way trade and more jobs—newer and better jobs—as a consequence of that additional trade.

I might add there was also consideration of aspects of financial transparency and work which the Treasurer and others have done and which the Prime Minister, from his task force, launched. I am delighted that, in reviewing all of APEC at this time as it heads to the leaders meeting in September in Auckland, it has to be said that the management of the Asian meltdown was conducted a whole lot better as a consequence of the existence of APEC. The bringing forward of a recovery, most notably in places like Korea, was facilitated by the additional confidence, contact and networking conferred by APEC when some very hard decisions had to be made, including by the Australian government.

There is a bonus for Darwin out of the deliberations in New Zealand these last three or four days, and that is that Brunei has invited Australia to be the host for this trade ministers meeting this time next year—mid-year 2000—and the good news is that, on my recommendation, Darwin has been selected for that. It will be a very good boost for the Brunei year of APEC that Darwin will host the trade ministers meeting, especially as Brunei is seeking to develop the theme of service industries and tourism for its APEC year. All in all, a very constructive, successful meeting. But I sadly have to report to the House there is still no such thing as a level playing field.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Cooperative Research Centres

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. What is your response to the letter sent to you on 2 June by the President of the Liberal Party, Tony Staley, warning that the GST has `the potential to adversely affect the operations of all cooperative research centres'? Did you tell Mr Staley that he was wrong when he suggested that a cooperative research centre with a cash income of $2½ million per annum could be liable to a GST of $700,000? Did you tell Mr Staley he was wrong to suggest that grants from industrial parties to cooperative research centres and in-kind contributions from businesses could be subject to a GST?

—I am aware that the honourable member released a report of a letter from Mr Staley to me dated 2 June 1999. I thank her for doing so, because it certainly brought it to my attention and it means that her attempt to mislead the House can be refuted. I have the letter from Mr Staley. In it he posed a number of questions and asked for answers in relation to them.

answer.para: The answers to Mr Staley's questions are that the GST will not adversely impact on government grants to cooperative research centres and, where a grant is a payment by a government that constitutes a consideration for a supply of services, they will be subject to GST only when the CRC is a registered entity. This means that if it is a registered entity—

talk.start.para: —They are.
—Just wait for it—it can claim the full amount of the GST as an input tax credit.
—Yes, it is.

—They say it is, and the consequence of it is that they get all of it back. One of the things that has amazed me in this whole debate as it has gone through the House of Representatives is that not one person in the Labor Party has been able to do the work to actually understand how tax applies—not one of them. A registered entity is entitled to claim back as an input tax credit all of the GST paid. That is the whole idea. Businesses do not pay tax on inputs. It is only under Labor's tax system that business pays tax under inputs.
—And what about passing it on?
—The Leader of the Opposition!

—Because Labor's tax, the wholesale sales tax, when you buy something with wholesale sales tax on it, you are not entitled to claim it back. That is the difference. They have always brought with them the fatal weakness of their own flawed taxation system and sought to objectify it onto tax reform.
—But you didn't say that when you—
—The member for Wills is warned.

—The provider of the grant will therefore be able to claim an input tax credit in relation to the grant, and the grant recipient will be able to remit the GST to the Australian Taxation Office. Because the transaction is one between two GST registered entities, it will have no net GST effect on either the CRC or the provider of the grant. And that being the case, the CRCs are in a protected position.
—It is a tax on knowledge!
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—The CRCs will benefit from tax reform because they will be able to give all of their input tax credits back. I welcome the interest of Mr Staley in writing to me and I am very pleased to be able to have this opportunity to give him the answers in relation to that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, could you inform the House of the many benefits which have accrued to the Australian community from the introduction of the Workplace Relations Act? Has this act measured up to the expectations of various parties?

—I thank the member for Moreton for his question. In April 1997 the Labor Party actually set the benchmark, the criteria, by which the 1996 Workplace Relations Act reforms should be assessed and I think—2½ years on since the commencement of those reforms—it is only fair enough to judge ourselves against the test which the Labor Party set for us. The then shadow minister, the member for Fraser, said there were five questions to be asked about the government's reforms. The first one was: will there be fewer industrial disputes over this three-year term under this regime than there were in the last three years under the old regime? As members of the House know, we got the lowest level of industrial disputes since 1913 in both 1997 and 1998—one out of one we passed that test.

answer.para: The second Labor test was: will there be more jobs created in this term under this regime than there were in the last parliament? In particular, will there be more jobs created in small business? Of course unemployment is not good enough but it is the lowest basically for this decade. Youth unemployment is about the lowest since the early 1980s. Importantly, we have created more jobs than Labor destroyed during `the recession that we had to have'. In Labor's last six years there were 24,300 full-time jobs created; under the coalition, 407,000. Half of those were full time and about half of them were created in small business. So that is two questions out of two.

The third one was: will the distribution of wage outcomes and benefits be fairer after this act than it was before? That is an easy one to answer. If you are a low income person, real wages have increased by 7½ per cent in the time that we have been in; they declined by five per cent under Labor's 13 years—so that is three out of three. His fourth test was: will labour productivity increase faster after this act than the current trend rate of 1.75 per cent per annum? The Treasurer has already answered that question. Productivity rates are at a very high level, certainly significantly better than they were when Labor was in. That is four out of four.

Lastly: will the overall wage and salary outcomes be more consistent with a low inflation, low interest rate environment than the outcomes of the present system? Interest rates are at the lowest since the bloke walked on the moon. As for interest rates: not only do you get an increase in your wage packet but $330 a month in the average reduction in mortgage rates and of course low inflation. And who is helped by low inflation? None other than the low income folk, those people who are otherwise disadvantaged in the labour market. Those are the tests that the Labor Party set. The official statistics show we have met five out of five. The importance of that fact is that we are now proceeding to the second set of reforms, building on what we have done in 1996, confident in the knowledge that the runs are on the board—more jobs, more employment, higher wages—and that is a good deal for the Australian economy.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Transport Costs

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Minister, will you confirm that a bus company in Sydney operating a daily minibus service to Mittagong will get a diesel fuel grant for all of the 108-kilometre journey but another bus company in Sydney operating a daily minibus service to Wollongong—a similar 100 kilometres—will not get a grant for any of the journey? Isn't this inequity going to provide a competitive disadvantage—something that you claim to care about—to bus companies servicing areas like Wollongong, Newcastle and outer metropolitan Sydney? As transport minister, do you believe that these areas deserve a lesser service than non-metropolitan areas?
—My response to the honourable member for Dickson's question is to say to her that the package is not quite as we originally designed it.
—Oh, ha, ha!
—That is apparently hilariously funny. But I would have thought that that was quite apparent.
—You promised to resign!
—Resign! Where is your resignation?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the member for Dickson!

—It delivers overwhelmingly the benefits that we promised to rural and regional Australia. In fact, the package as a whole may offer better benefits to rural and regional Australia. There are some changes to the arrangements as a result of what we successfully negotiated with the Democrats. I regret, I have to say to the member for Dickson, that she dealt herself—and her party—out of the opportunity to perhaps have smoothed over, to have streamlined, some of these areas for which she now professes great concern about. But that was not possible and the responsibility for that decision lies not with us, not with the Democrats but with you.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Price Reductions

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. What will be done to ensure Australian consumers gain the full benefit of price reductions during the introduction of the new tax system?

—I would like to thank the member for Fadden for his question; he has long been a strong advocate for consumer interests. Twenty-one days after the royal assent is given for the bills that passed through the parliament yesterday, tax cuts begin. The wholesale sales tax applying to luxury goods will be brought down from 32 per cent to 22 per cent. These goods, as the Treasurer said in the House yesterday, include clocks, television sets, hi-fi systems, cameras, watches, radios, cufflinks and tie-pins. For the information of the Labor Party, they also include amusement machines, which should ensure that membership fees for the Labor Party come down as well.

answer.para: Fines will be put in place—of $10 million for companies and up to half a million dollars for individuals—for those who do not bring down the prices. I can advise the House that the ACCC has advised me that it has also surveyed retailers in over 100 cities and towns across Australia, specifically focusing on rural and regional Australia. They have a basket of goods from individual stores in those cities and towns as a price guide and a comparison with the price that should be applied after the wholesale sales tax comes down.

As an indication of the broad range of basket that the ACCC has gathered, it covers, interestingly enough, representatives from both sides of the House and towns ranging from Alice Springs in the Northern Territory, from the seat of the member for Northern Territory through to the Gold Coast, Charters Towers, Longreach, Maitland, Bega, Orange, Glen Innes, Canberra, Bendigo, Hamilton, Bairnsdale, Launceston, Whyalla, Broome and a number of other centres. We can also advise the House that the ACCC has a new commissioner dealing with GST prices surveillance, that being Dr David Cousins. That was announced earlier today.

talk.start.para: —The member for Melbourne will have time to reflect if he does not exercise some more restraint.

—The ACCC will be working closely with the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that, to the satisfaction of the member for Fadden, consumers are better off through the GST application. I can advise the House that if consumers do have any complaints about that process then they should ring the ACCC on 1300 302 502 to ensure that retailers are bringing down the prices, which is good news for Australian consumers.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Minister, will you confirm that a transport company in Coolangatta operating a fleet of 10-tonne trucks will not get a diesel fuel grant for any journeys to metropolitan areas, includ ing to Brisbane, whereas a business competitor in Murwillumbah—just 29 kilometres away—will get a grant for all journeys, especially to Brisbane? Why are you requiring these businesses to compete on such an unlevel playing field? Wouldn't any sensible transport company in an outer metropolitan area like Coolangatta or Ipswich in my electorate of Oxley simply up and move to the nearest non-metropolitan area?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 146, which clearly states that a question, once fully answered, cannot be reviewed.
—He never answered it, you idiot.

—The member for Bruce. If members on my left imagine that either the Speaker or the general public are going to put up with that sort of derision, they are sorely mistaken. The member for Page has the call and is entitled, under standing order 55, to be heard without interruption.
—Mr Speaker, I put to you that this question has been answered fully on several occasions.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: the most profound problem with the point of order is that this question could not have been answered because it is distinctly different from all those which have been asked before. The second point is that those questions which were asked before were not fully answered.
—Mr Speaker—
—The patience of the chair is being sorely tested by points of order. I trust this one is not frivolous and call the member for Kingston.
—On the point of order, Mr Speaker: I do not think any of these questions have been answered at all.

—I warn the member for Kingston. I will rule on the point of order of the member for Page. The question asked earlier today of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services referred to bus journeys between two destinations. This is a question that refers to truck journeys between two destinations and, as such, is in order. I call the minister.

—I thank the honourable member for the question. The first point I would make is that, if the truck operating in a conurbation is over 20 tonnes when it is loaded, it gets the full benefit of all the transportation tax relief measures. The second point I would make is that, if it is between 4½ tonnes and 20 tonnes and operating in a conurbation like that, no, it does not get the full benefit. That is known. There is no new fresh revelation in that. The third point I would make is this: all of those truck operators benefit from the abolition of something that, as the Treasurer suggested yesterday, you are evidently going to argue that we ought to bring back at the next election—the WST. It all goes. It is one of the major cost imposts on the transport industry, and it goes. What is more, they get the GST on their fuel back.

answer.para: The next point I would make is in relation to where they might choose to locate. The relief or the taxation concessions are not based around where the truck is registered; it is based around where the fuel is used and what it is used for. The final point I would make is that what needs to be recognised is that, on this issue, you are opposing a valuable set of reforms for rural and regional Australia. You are against them. I want to quote some remarks made in Queensland the other day by an interviewer talking to United Graziers Association President, Noel Kennedy. The interviewer comments that Noel Kennedy believes that the cut to diesel fuel is the most significant part of the GST package for regional and remote Queensland.

He says that it will benefit all people who live in remote areas and not just the people who operate a business—a grazing or a mining business. He said that it will benefit the people who live there and the actual cost of living in these remote areas. Freight is a big component of their costs, and of course this will be reduced. He also said that it will either do one of two things: it will reduce the cost of their living or it will improve the quality of life. I suggest it will do both. The bottom line is quite simply that you do not want people in rural and regional Australia to have the massive benefits that flow out of this very worthwhile reform.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister advise the House how the government's research discussion paper seeks to improve our nation's research efforts? How does the minister respond to comments which have been made regarding the government's efforts to boost Australia's role in the ideas economy?
—He just counts the first eight years of Labor in his 10.
—It's called shifting deckchairs on the Titanic .

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for his question. The interjections are coming from a party which, as I said, intended to actually cut research funding in the course of its last announced education policy. The discussion paper on research and research training issued by the government is an expression of the government's determination to strengthen Australia's research base and to make sure that the brilliant ideas of Australian researchers have the best possible chance of being developed in Australia.

answer.para: Australia as a nation has shown that it is very strong in producing outstanding research and brilliant ideas. Too often those ideas have been developed overseas where the jobs have been located overseas when they could have been in Australia. This research paper aims to create a more entrepreneurial climate in Australian research and in the scientific community. Nor can Australia afford to keep losing the best and brightest of its young researchers. Its young scientists are going overseas as a result of the restrictive policies that the Labor Party supported for 13 years. This paper and the proposals in this paper will start to bring back to Australia the best and brightest of our young researchers.

The comparative advantage of Australia in the 21st century will be because its economy is an ideas economy. Australia is going to find that its comparative advantage is in its knowledge and ideas, and the policies proposed in this green paper will help to position Australian research so that it is world class across the board. I am pleased to be able to tell the House that Professor Vicki Sara, the Chair of the Australian Research Council, has said that the paper is `an important step forward for the development of Australia's innovation system'.

This government has invested in research. It has put far more money into university research than the Labor Party ever put into university research. Australia is already making a very big investment in scientific research and research in other areas. What this paper is concerned with is getting the national strategy right. We have to make sure that there is an entrepreneurial climate in that research, that there are incentives to commercialise their research, that there are incentives to critical mass so young researchers can feel that they can continue their careers and work in Australia in an environment which will enable them to give it their best.

One of the interesting proposals in this paper is $2 million for the Prime Minister's scholarships. The Prime Minister's scholarships will provide assistance to the most promising honours graduates in Australia's universities who are proposing to go on to doctoral research. This is a recognition of the fact that this paper is all about excellence: it is about encouraging the best that Australia can do so that the best ideas and the best knowledge can support prosperity and jobs in this country into the 21st century.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Rail Services

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Has the minister seen claims by FCL Interstate Transport Services that the 10 per cent GST on rail related goods and services will far outweigh the savings on excise from the rail industry and put rail at a further competitive disadvantage to road? Does the minister agree with the calculations of Mr Gibbins, FCL's managing director, that post GST road compared with rail will be at least six per cent more cost efficient than rail? If not, has the minister or the government carried out any assessment of how the GST and the savings on excise will ultimately impact on the rail industry?
—I thank the honourable member for her question. The first thing that comes to mind is that I suspect again what we are seeing here is a failure to understand that all business costs are rebatable.
—In full.
—In full. But there is a serious national issue here and I want to touch on it briefly.
—Ah, this is the vision thing!

—The vision thing. Well, there you go. We see a lot of that from the ALP. It is a vision called oppose absolutely everything, whatever it is, and if it is good for the country oppose it even more vigorously.
—The minister will respond to the question.

—The fact of the matter is that we are removing all excise on rail. That is not something you have put up as a proposal. I believe that will assist the long-term competitiveness for rail. The short answer to your question about long-term prospects for rail is that, yes, we have done quite a bit of work on it and what we have established is that rail will continue to enjoy the advantage—
—He has his trainers on, Tim.

—Mr Speaker, they are apparently not interested in the answer. But I thought it was quite an interesting point that the long-term advantages rail enjoys in long distance heavy freight haulage not only will be maintained but also are likely to be increased because our GST package will promote growth. More growth means a greater task for transport. That means more opportunity for both road and rail, and in the area where rail has an advantage it is our belief, based on research that we have done, that rail can look forward to a very bright future, particularly if we can gain a competitive regulatory environment across the jurisdiction of this country and if we can undo some of the damage that was done to rail in the years when you were in power.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Can the minister advise the House what progress has been made in implementing higher mass limits for the transport industry?
—I thank the honourable member for his question. He is a man who holds the largest electorate in the world, let alone in Australia.
—He knows a bit about transport.
—He knows a bit about transport and he knows how important it is.
—He knows a bit about campaigning, too.

—Yes, he knows a bit about campaigning. The parliament yesterday passed some bills which means that collectively transport has had a great week in Australia. It is the lifeblood of the economy, particularly in rural and regional areas. So I want to announce that there is another big win which will commence unrolling tomorrow—that is, what is known as higher mass limits will begin to unroll.

answer.para: For the layman, this means that trucks will now be allowed to carry more freight per load—less trucks delivering more economical usage of our fuel. It will mean, in short, that a semitrailer, which at the moment is legally limited to carry 42½ tonnes, will be able to carry 45½ tonnes. To the layman again, I reassure people that it does not mean more trucks; it means fewer trucks because they can load more effectively. It is worth, believe it or not, something in the order of an $840 million a year boost to gross domestic product—benefits to consumers, the farm sector, the mining sector, fuel distribution, logging, food manufacturing, in short, to all Australians.

I would like to say that my ministerial counterparts in Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory showed early and strong support for this. South Australia has had higher mass limits since January of this year. Western Australia and the Northern Territory have had them in part for several years. Tasmania has also agreed. Yesterday Queensland agreed, which is a great outcome. We await a reply from the ACT. But I heard somebody opposite say, `Where is Mr Carr on this?' Mr Carr is dragging his heels. Mr Carr claims to be at the forefront of transport reform, but his minister Carl Scully is saying that they are not going to allow for the unrolling of higher mass limits in this country.

Mass limits are a very major reform for transport in this country, with trucks loading more effectively, fewer trucks and lower fuel usage. We are putting in real resources to upgrade bridges across the nation to help the unrolling. It is time that New South Wales came on side with this very important reform, that they stop resisting the sorts of reforms that we see also in the area of the waterfront.

I note in closing that the member who asked this question will be interested to learn that among the 13 new enterprise agreements signed recently by P&O is one for Port Hedland. It will make a real difference again to the transport efficiency in his electorate.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Minister, do you recall announcing on 2 December last year that you had commissioned an expert consultant to conduct an independent investigation into the vibration and stability of Kenworth and certain other heavy trucks? Will you confirm that you and the Federal Office of Road Safety now have the report? Can you confirm that the report finds that design faults on the suspension mean that certain heavy vehicles are inherently unsafe and that it recommends that these vehicles should be recalled immediately? When do you propose to release these findings, get off your seat, take these unstable and dangerous vehicles off our roads and help prevent more death and injury on our major highways?

—In response to the honourable member's question I really think that, ahead of the report, which has not been completed, he does himself, the Labor Party, the transport industry and, in particular, the manufacturers of certain trucks in this country a great disservice by making assumptions that should not yet be made. It is true that, entirely appropriately and responsibly for a transport minister in this country, in response to various allegations being made, I have indeed initiated an inquiry. That is under way. But for a number of reasons, including a very interesting set of attitudes by some of the legal people in this country, it has taken much longer than anticipated to complete that review. Due to the complexity of the issues involved, the investigation has been extended. I expect a draft report soon. But I would suggest that, in the interests of fair play and common decency, we not make these sorts of assumptions about people who may prove to have been unfairly and grossly maligned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment Services. Is the minister aware of any recent public statements regarding the Work for the Dole scheme, which is strongly supported by people in the electorate of Blair? What is the government's response to such statements?

—I thank the member for Blair for his question and for his interest in this great program and for recently visiting the Work for the Dole team that was doing environmental restoration on the banks of the Bremer River in his electorate. I am aware of recent public statements about the Work for the Dole program, particularly an adjournment speech last night by the member for Batman, which he described as a fairly significant statement from the Australian Labor Party, presumably to distinguish it from statements from the Leader of the Opposition, whose net satisfaction rating has dropped by 13 points in just six weeks.
—The minister will come to the question.
—The statement of the member for Batman last night was in fact a significant challenge to the authority of the Leader of the Opposition, who has consistently called—
—Tell us about the polls.
—The member for Melbourne is warned.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on repetition. I think this is the 28th occasion that the minister has answered a question on the supposed positive statements about Work for the Dole. He simply varies the electorate. Now he goes into a criticism of a member of this side. He ignores the question. I ask you to draw him back to it.

—If the member for Paterson had been listening, he would have heard the chair interrupt the minister when he made what I felt was a less than constructive observation. And I was in the chair last night when the member for Batman made his constructive speech about the Work for the Dole scheme. Given the fact that this was referenced to the electorate of Blair, I was presuming that the question had not been answered in full; that is why I called the minister. I invite him to come back to the question.

—The Leader of the Opposition has consistently called Work for the Dole social punishment. He has called it a disgracefully shoddy piece of public policy. Yet last night in the chamber we had the member for Batman calling for community organisations to become involved in what his leader thinks is a disgracefully shabby piece of public policy. The member for Batman gave the game away a few moments later when he called for a return to Working Nation style training programs, even though he knows—because the member for Melbourne has told him—that these lead to perverse outcomes and inappropriate and even demoralising training. That is even though he knows—because the Leader of the Opposition has told him:

answer.para: It is true that out of a lot of our training programs people didn't get a job at the end of it. But . . . they weren't around the streets bothering anybody.

So that is the kind of shabby, shoddy training that the member for Batman is calling for in replacement of Work for the Dole. The real question is: has the ALP dropped its opposition to Work for the Dole? The answer is: of course it has not. What the member for Batman was doing last night was simply acknowledging the great public support for this great program. If the ALP were serious about supporting Work for the Dole, it would not give lectures to community organisations, it would tell the union movement to drop its opposition to this program, it would tell the New South Wales AWU to drop its veto on Work for the Dole programs in New South Wales national parks. That is the real test of whether the ALP is serious about for Work for the Dole: is it prepared to take on the unions? That is a test the Labor Party always flunks.

subdebateinfo.title: Fishing: Imports of Canadian Uncooked Salmon

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Minister, what action do you propose to take in response to the World Trade Organisation directive that, by 6 July, Australia must agree to allow Canadian uncooked salmon into Australia? If you intend to allow the salmon imports, what is your assessment of the consequences for the salmon industry and for the Australian recreational fishing industry and what is your plan to cope with these consequences? If you do not intend to follow the directive, what support will you provide to the 52 primary products, including sheep, fruit, fish and flowers, which the Canadian government has listed for retaliatory action, including an import tax of up to 100 per cent?

question.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There will be no exchange across the parliament. The member for Melbourne seems to have a very short memory, and the member for Jagajaga isn't a lot better.

—I thank the honourable member for his question. From the outset, I think that we should acknowledge that we take our obligations as far as international trade very seriously. We, through the Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister, have become a major player on the world stage in terms of trade negotiations and progressing the ideals of the Cairns Group. We have achieved a great deal in that regard.

answer.para: As far as the position that Canada have taken in advance of Australia fulfilling its obligations under this WTO decision, which is the issue that the member asked about, Canada are probably being a little bit provocative in identifying what retaliatory action they are taking and indeed going to the WTO when the WTO decision was about Australia completing an import risk analysis process by a particular date. That date has not arrived yet. We have announced that AQIS is undertaking that import risk analysis process.

talk.start.para: —You have to do that before it does happen.

—No. It is undertaking that analysis, and we will meet our obligations under the WTO. An interesting point to make is that earlier this year on 1 March, the shadow spokespersons, I suppose, for trade and agriculture, Senator Cook and the member for Corio, put out a joint statement, `Salmon decision: the government must act'. It says:

answer.para: One possibility would be to accelerate the Import Risk Assessment on fresh salmon, currently due to report early next year. As long as it is careful to preserve the integrity of Australia's Risk Assessment process the government would be wise to investigate whether this process can be completed before 6 July 1999.
For once, the Labor Party agrees with the position the government has taken.

talk.start.para: —But what are you going to do?

—We have taken that position. The truncated import risk analysis process is under way right now. We will stand by the integrity of the scientific basis of that process, and we will meet our WTO obligations.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor: Attack on United Nations Personnel

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister inform the House of the government's response to the violent attack on the United Nations office in the town of Maliana, East Timor? What action has the Australian government taken following the attack?

—I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for her question and her concern about the attack in the town of Maliana on a number of United Nations personnel. The Australian government is seriously concerned about the attack on United Nations personnel in Maliana. We understand that somewhere in the vicinity of 12 United Nations personnel were injured, although I have been advised that no Australians were injured.

answer.para: The United Nations, Australia and the international community as a whole will not, of course, be bullied by thugs. We will not be bullied out of this United Nations process and we will not be bullied into abandoning the United Nations supervised ballot in East Timor. The Indonesian authorities are, as members are no doubt aware, investigating this incident.

Last night I took the opportunity of speaking to the Indonesian ambassador about this incident, and I made it clear that the Australian government deplores this kind of violence directed against the United Nations. On my instructions, our ambassador in Jakarta, John McCarthy, also made representations at the highest level in the Indonesian department of foreign affairs. He was not able to speak to the foreign minister because Mr Alatas was absent in Burkina Faso.

talk.start.para: —Why didn't you ring Alatas?
—The member for Kingsford-Smith!
—Mr McCarthy took the opportunity of reiterating our grave concern, and the ambassador did make the point that the Indonesian police had failed in their duty to provide protection.

answer.para: The incident in Maliana should underline without any doubt to Indonesia that the concerns that we and others have, in particular that the United Nations have, about security in East Timor are real. The international community does expect Indonesia to fulfil its obligations under the tripartite agreement agreed in New York to protect UNAMET personnel. We have, of course, consistently made our concerns known to the Indonesians.

talk.start.para: —Argued against peacekeeping: that is what you have done.
—I hear the member for Kingsford-Smith, back on his cheap party political points. You had 13 years to fix up the East Timor problem. You did not bother in 13 years.
—The minister will come to the question and the member for Kingsford-Smith will exercise more restraint.
—I do not recall the Labor Party organising a summit with President Suharto to discuss the issue of East Timor ever. You never had the courage to do that.
—And they didn't go to East Timor to discuss it either.

—The Prime Minister makes a rather significant point. You certainly did not travel up to Indonesia to lobby on the issue of East Timor. The Prime Minister did. The Prime Minister met with President Habibie in order to discuss Australia's concerns about the security environment in East Timor. We have made something like 50 representations since March on the issue of the security environment in East Timor.

answer.para: In conclusion, I was only going to give the House an update on the situation and what we had done. The constant cackling of the Labor Party reminds us of what could be described as sickening hypocrisy. You had 13 years to address the issue of East Timor and you cry crocodile tears now. If it was such a big issue, why did you do nothing about it for 13 years? You hypocrites!

talk.start.para: —The minister will resume his seat.
—I have finished.
—Mr Speaker, I have a point of order. The minister was asked a specific question relating to a problem now.

interjection.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am hearing the Leader of the Opposition.
—He was asked a specific question on that. The simple fact of the matter is that he and his Prime Minister have failed miserably at a moment of great opportunity.
—The Leader of the Opposition cannot argue the case and will resume his seat.
—You are a pathetic Leader of the Opposition.
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs! The Leader of the Opposition cannot expect recognition from the chair, which is rightly extended to him, if he abuses the recognition when it is extended.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Forestry and Conservation.
—You didn't even have the courage to ask a question about it! You are absolutely pathetic!
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs is warned.

—Is the minister aware that the Deputy Premier of Western Australia yesterday told the Western Australian parliament that the National Party had identified a list of blocks which have `high conservation value but which fall outside the reservation processes'? Will you permit the Western Australian government to include these blocks in the reserve system? If not, why not?

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The first thing I noticed reported in the press today was that the Leader of the National Party told the state parliament that the Western Australian Premier did tell me that there would be no change to the regional forest agreement which the Premier and the Prime Minister signed some weeks ago. That is a matter of record in the parliamentary Hansard in Western Australia.

answer.para: We are well aware that certain people from time to time identify other blocks that might be included in the reserve system. I went and had a look at one of them through my department. I think it might have been Jane Block, but I will stand corrected on its title. It was about 5,000 hectares and represented 15,000 cubic meters of saw logs. If that one single block was added to the reserve system negotiated under the JANIS criteria and the national forest policy statement—which was once written by the Labor government; and once written oft forgotten is their practice—if that one block was transferred from production to reservation, 70 to 80 direct jobs would be lost. That seems to be what this minister cautions about. All he wants to do is try to raise a situation here where there would be further job losses in the forest industries.

When the Prime Minister signed that agreement, I was so proud to be able to stand up and say to a town that is extremely vulnerable to this process, the town of Nannup, that the people of Nannup could sleep tonight. It is only due to the fact that the Labor Party will not support the regional forest agreement legislation in the Senate that we are not able to stand here now adding that reassurance to the people of the forest industries around Australia who are extremely worried. The major party—the now party of total irrelevance—is unable to bring itself to support this. We have got the Oxford scholars faction now running the Labor Party on forest issues. They do not care about working people. They wake up every morning and think there is some new party that is not called the Labor Party. The Labor Party used to be committed—as the spokesman on industrial relations has reminded his own side—to putting jobs first.

The regional forest agreement is a process that addresses environmental issues under a strict criteria and, in Western Australia, that criteria was met. It also addresses the social impact on people and, for the benefit of the people opposite, that social impact means whether or not they are going to lose their house.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I have a point of order on relevance.
—The minister will resume his seat.
—I have finished.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. Can the minister inform the House of recent opportunities that exist for Australia to become a world financial centre?

—I thank the member for Menzies for his pertinent question. Yesterday was an historic step forward in our ambitions to become a global financial centre. It was a historic day forward because the parliament passed two very important pieces of legislation that make us world competitive and, in many ways, ahead of much of the world.

answer.para: In the first place, we have got something to boast about in Australia that other parts of the region have not. We have got the second largest stock market in the Asia-Pacific region. We have got the largest futures market in the Asia-Pacific region. We have got the sixth largest funds under management of any nation in the world. As of reports this morning, the Australian dollar is now the fifth most traded currency in the world after the euro, the US, the sterling and the yen. That is an indication of just how successful Australia is in getting its message across to the world that we are a good place to do business in. Much of the credit goes to the work already done by the government and, in particular, by the Minister for Trade, who has gone to Asia and sent a great message to Asia—to Thailand, Hong Kong and Singapore—about our ambitions and successes and the great strength of the Australian economy.

Yesterday two very important pieces of legislation passed the parliament. The first one was Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). That provides a number of tax initiatives, announced some time ago by the government but implemented now, that encourage foreign financial institutions to provide services to Australian consumers, particularly in terms of funds management. Another initiative in that piece of legislation takes the shackles off foreign investors who want to invest in Australian corporate bonds. All of the people in this House should be aware that the Aussie Home Loans and the RAMS of this world issue bonds on the Australian market. If money is cheaper for Aussie, money is cheaper for all Aussies. The benefit of that comes down to lower interest rates for mums and dads. That is what we want.

Other initiatives in that bill are a significant step forward, but no initiative is more significant than the billions of dollars we have provided as an incentive for Australian mums and dads to invest in the stock market. The best way to do that is to abolish stamp duty on the transfer of shares. Why does the Labor Party oppose these initiatives? Why does the Labor Party oppose greater access for Australian mums and dads to the stock market?

talk.start.para: —They do not have the money to be able to invest on the stock market.
—The member for Paterson interrupts. The member for Paterson has obviously had his mojo stolen in the last 24 hours. The member for Paterson, who models himself on Austin Powers—
—You are no Felicity Shagwell.
—I wouldn't be talking about shagging.
—Order! The House will come to order. What was clearly a matter of levity across the House has now degenerated somewhat. I bring the minister back to the question.
—Well, Mr Speaker, they might be encouraged that the price of studs has come down from 32 per cent to 22 per cent.
—The minister will come to the question.

—The bottom line is this. The government is doing everything it can to facilitate greater share ownership in Australia. That means that more foreign investors are coming to Australia. It means that more of the world's capital is coming to Australia. The good news is that that means more jobs for Australians.

—My question is to the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. Are you aware that the Premier of Western Australia refused yesterday in state parliament to confirm your story to this House that he had told you on Saturday that the state government had no plans to change the RFA and add more reserves? Did the Premier refuse to confirm your story because you didn't accurately reflect either the tenor or outcome of the meeting, or did he refuse because he won't fess up in his own state to his failure to achieve what he promised the people of Western Australia—to change the RFA and add more reserves?

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The press reporting, of course, is slightly misrepresented in the question, and that is not an unusual event. My reading of the press reporting was that the Premier made no comment, but the Deputy Premier then announced to the parliament that the Premier had told him that they were not changing the arrangements. All the evidence I note in the media is that the Western Australian coalition has resolved an issue that represented some difficulty for them. There was clearly very vigorous debate within their party room and their cabinet on the issue. It is pretty clear from today's press reporting, I am pleased to say, that the Western Australian government did what people of honour would always have done, and stuck to their agreements and stuck to their policy. In this House that is easy to differentiate. There is our side and there is their side. This is the side that can be identified as sticking to policy and promoting policy in a way that creates both jobs and conservation, in this case according to the national forest policy statement.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the extract from the Hansard that will give the accurate picture of the circumstances.

interjection.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —Has the Prime Minister seen recent comments by political leaders concerning the need to adopt positive attitudes to important public issues? What is the Prime Minister's response to these comments?

—Mr Speaker, could I say in reply to the member for Ballarat, and an outstanding Chief Government Whip, that as it transpires I have seen a comment on that very issue. That comment came from none other than a successful Labor leader, and that successful Labor leader is the Premier of New South Wales. He had this to say:

answer.para: I think the electorate is telling political leaders these days to come up with positive approaches.
This is the really relevant bit:
Don't waste your time just attacking the other side. We are sick of that.

That could well be a piece of political advice that the Leader of the Opposition could take on his travels around Australia over the next five or six weeks because if there is one thing that distinguishes our side from the other side, particularly over the eight months that have gone by since the last election, it is that the Liberal and National parties have got on with the job. They have delivered on what they promised to do. One of the most conspicuous features of a very conspicuous budget delivered by the Treasurer in May was that we were able to announce in that budget the implementation in full of all of the promises we took to the Australian people in October of last year. Not one of those promises was left out. The Treasurer was able to put a document on the table demonstrating conclusively that we had implemented all of our promises.

Lest anybody in this House imagine for a moment that in my comments I am adopting a partisan stance, can I refer to an editorial in the Melbourne Herald Sun today. It is under the headline of `The sidelined ALP'. I think it really deserves very, very careful study. This is what it had to say:
Having contributed nothing positive to tax reform, Opposition Leader Kim Beazley has the cheek to criticise the government's deal with the Democrats.
His own lack of leadership on this issue saw the ALP sidelined in the negotiations which were critical to the nation's future.
Yesterday, in a deplorable exercise in negativism, Mr Beazley described the new tax system as "a complete mess". He also mocked the government's attempt to achieve a 100 per cent Telstra sale.
Instead of responding to reality by isolating the minority senators, they allowed Labor to be reduced to a rump.
The outcomes on both tax reform and Telstra are far from ideal. But Mr Beazley cannot credibly denigrate the Howard Government's compromise.

What you have there is a very accurate analysis. On one side of politics in Australia at the moment you have two political parties that are prepared to put the national interest ahead of the sectional interest. You have two political parties—the Liberal and National parties—which are prepared to take risks for the long-term benefit of this country. You have two political parties—the Liberal Party and the National Party—which are committed to long-term benefits for the people of Australia. On the other side you have a political party that is wallowing in negativism, a political party that lives by saying no and shaking its head, a political party that is led by a man who has given no political leadership over the last three years. It is also led by a man who is now losing any touch with political reality. I turned on my radio this morning to hear him being interviewed by Fran Kelly of the ABC, and his very first answer in response to a question from Fran Kelly was:
Look, we have mounted a full-blown assault on this GST, and we have won the debate.

All I can say is that I tremble to think of what he would say if he had thought he had lost the debate. It has been a very satisfying first eight months, satisfying because we have been able to do good things for the people of Australia. Governments are elected and political parties come into this place to stand for principles, to fight for programs to achieve goals, to achieve objectives—not to feed their egos, but to deliver long-term benefits for the people of Australia. I am very pleased and proud that we have done that. We will go on doing that. I thank my colleagues for the contributions that they have made to that.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, can you confirm to the parliament that the personnel working at the parliamentary switchboard are no longer being provided by Telstra but by the Kelly Services employment agency? Could you also confirm that there are some very experienced personnel who had worked with the parliamentary switch for many years who had wished to continue working but who were not offered positions by Kelly and were instead replaced by new inexperienced staff? Can you investigate why those former experienced employees who have served this parliament and all members and senators so well were not kept on by Kelly? Finally, have you received any complaints about the level of service being provided by Kelly?

—I will respond to the question. I cannot confirm what the member for Cunningham has said. I have not received any complaints but, yes, I will investigate the questions he has asked and, at a convenient time, report back to the parliament.

debateinfo.title: LEADER OF THE NATIONAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA: RESIGNATION

talk.start.para: —by leave—I have had personal and particular cause to change my mind and bring forward a decision which I now present to the House as a matter of courtesy and to avoid any misleading. I announce that, as a consequence of the convergence of certain political factors and certain personal factors, I have decided to step down as federal Leader of the National Party, as Deputy Prime Minister of Australia and, not without a degree of particular regret, as Minister for Trade. I propose to do so on or about 20 July.

speech.para: I plan to continue as the member for Farrer. I plan to continue a deep interest in issues such as trade, transport and tourism, within and without the political realm. I plan to activate a personal tourism industry project. I plan also to do something quaint, perhaps over this next couple of weeks—that is, to travel around to some places, large and small, to say thank you to the people of Australia for the assistance, help and support they have given me over the period that I have had the privilege of serving in these positions.

After 30 years directly involved in politics, after a period in the Army, after 28 years in state and federal politics and some 20 years on the front bench, let me say that the timing is about right. The timing is about right in that the government is well established in its second term—the Prime Minister showing strong leadership, right through to question time a moment ago, and getting the job done. The taxation legislation is through; the diesel fuel excise abolition on rail—something we could have only dreamt about years ago—is now in legislation coming in on 1 July next year.

The timing is about right on the trade front inasmuch as the WTO China negotiations so far as Australia is concerned have now been completed. The preparations for the launch of a millennium trade round in the WTO are a given. It is perhaps best that the minister who will carry forward the burden of those detailed negotiations be at Seattle for the launch. There is also the extension of the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 that went through the Senate last night. That comes back later this afternoon for the final sign-off in this House. I must say I have enjoyed working with many international interlocutors on a raft of trade issues, and I express my thanks in respect of them.

The timing is not right in another sense in that there is always unfinished business. But I plan to craft this changeover date taking into account consultations and also to be on deck for any Washington decision on the lamb issue. But I guess there will always be decisions. We have done every single thing, and will continue to do every single thing, right down to the wire in relation to that particular decision—and each and every other trade decision whilst I have the privilege to be in this position. In any event, I say to those who have urged that I might stay that I ask for your understanding and your forbearance, but I guess in another sense it is better to go while there are some urging you to stay than might otherwise be the case.

It is for others to judge my contribution to state or federal politics. I would simply want to thank a number of people, particularly, on this occasion, my wife Judy, without whose support I could not have done this. I thank you, Judy.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—I would like to thank my family. I would like to thank electors in the electorates of Sturt and Murray in the state parliament and Farrer in the federal parliament these last 15 years. I would like to thank the National Party organisation and members, officials of the Boree Creek branch through to the Farrer electorate council through to federal presidents such as John Paterson, now Mayor of Nedlands, and Don McDonald, Mayor arguably of the Diamantina and Devoncourt. They have given me great help and guidance. I would like to thank members of the parliamentary National Party—my Deputy Leader, John Anderson, and the Senate leader of all these years, Ron Boswell, who has been a great help and guide. We have not agreed on everything, I will confess, but we have got the job done. I want to thank my Senate team—I am pleased to see them on the floor of the House—and all my National Party colleagues I have worked with previously and during this parliamentary term.

speech.para: I would like to thank my cabinet colleagues. I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his very good help and guidance with his years of experience, and commend one other decision you do not read much about. That is his decision to set up a national security committee, about which I can say no more because of security reasons other than to say it is one of the most focused units of government, serving this country well. I commend all my cabinet colleagues. I regret that because I flew back from this Auckland conference late this morning I did not have an opportunity to speak with you earlier. I apologise to you and others for that. I particularly enjoyed working with my portfolio colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer, and with all my colleagues.

I would like to thank the parliamentary Liberal Party, and you, Mr Speaker. You gave me great guidance to and from Antarctica and also on the citrus industry issue, with former and current members for Mallee and Riverina—David Brownhill, Larry Anthony and others—to get that right. I very much enjoyed our contact over the years.

I would like to acknowledge and say I respect many of those opposite and in the Senate for the work that we have done in committees such as transport committees and the like over the years. This is a great parliament and it is a great privilege to be a member of this place.

Let me salute the officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade at all levels, led by Philip Flood and Ashton Calvert—a delight to work with and very professional—right through to people like Chris Lamb risking his life in Belgrade to try and bring about the release of Peter Wallace and Stephen Pratt. Bit by bit, let us hope that that will happen sooner rather than later. I salute the determination and dedication of officers of Austrade, led by Charles Jamieson and Peter Langhorne and chair Alan Jackson, as they help diversify our trading effort. Trade figures today are slightly better but there is a lot more work to be done. There can be no complacency. Likewise in respect of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation—Graeme Lawless and Ian Payne—and every other aspect of my portfolio. It has been a joy to work closely with some very professional public servants going about their work and facilitating our trade.

Finally, I would like to thank my own personal staff. My former chief of staff Craig Symon, my current chief of staff Jenelle Bonnor, the members of my staff present and, in the electorate office, Nina, Glenda and Lyn here today and so many others over the years who have helped me work through. I am very proud of my staff. I thank you sincerely. What I have done has been greatly helped and brought about by a team effort. Yes, I confess we have had our arguments, particularly with the Praetorian Guard who are my schedule staff, but that has been more my cause than theirs, I confess.

That leaves the media and one other grouping. To the media I would say this. It was about 12 months ago that you stopped calling me `idiosyncratic'. I knew then it was time to start thinking about getting out of politics. It is something wonderful about our democracy that you can be the boy from Boree Creek and get a fair hearing—as you can be 101 other people—in the course of our robust parliamentary democracy. I thank the media for our contact and liaison over the years. I guess in one form or another it will continue as I happily take a seat in the new session up on the back bench and work away on a range of issues.

Last and most importantly, to the people of Australia I would say this. As we approach a new century, a new millennium, and more particularly the 100 years of the Federation of Australia, let us be proud of our robust democracy and its diverse composition of the very membership of this House of Representatives. Back bench, middle bench, front bench, both sides, there is a great diversity in the composition of this House of Representatives. That factor alone contributes well to the robust nature of Australian democracy. Long may it continue.

Let me also say that we ought to be proud of the 100 years of achievement of Australia as it comes up next year—the efforts and achievements of the people of Australia, the parliament of Australia and the governments at the federal and other levels over that tremendous 100 years. Let us be proud Australians as, arguably, we have the most cohesive and economically capable continent and the most diverse and democratic continent anywhere in the world. Good luck, my colleagues. Good luck to you all and God bless you all.

para.inline: (Whereupon honourable members applauded the member for Farrer.)

talk.start.para: —by leave—Today is a day of very mixed emotions. It is a very sad day, in a sense, for the coalition and for many of your very close friends, Tim, among whom I am very proud to number myself. We are going to miss you, and miss you an enormous amount, in the higher councils of the government. I cannot let this opportunity go by without saying a few words of genuine affection towards you and recording my personal thanks to you for the tremendous loyalty that you have displayed towards me, the Liberal Party and the coalition government that we have had the honour of leading together over the last 3¼ years.

speech.para: I think we can all set aside our political differences on an occasion like this and recognise that government in modern Australia is difficult. No matter who is in office it is hard, and the bonds that exist between the senior people who lead a government are tremendously important. If those bonds are built on trust, respect and an understanding of each other's strengths as well as an understanding of each other's weaknesses, then the government will be successful and it will be conducted in an atmosphere of goodwill. I have to say to you, Tim, that no Prime Minister, no coalition leader, could have had a better friend, a firmer ally or a more dependable colleague in difficult times than I have had in you. You have been the epitome of loyalty and decency towards my prime ministership and my leadership of the coalition. You were in the 12 months leading up to our election in May 1996, and you have been ever since.

You have led the National Party now for over nine years. Although I am not a member of the National Party, I have been a bit of a student of it in different ways over the years; sometimes I have studied it a little more closely than on other occasions. I think it is fair to say that the last decade has probably been the most challenging period in the existence of the National Party because, as a party that still primarily draws its support from rural and regional Australia, it has had to deal with the incredible change that has gone on in rural and regional Australia as the consequences of globalisation bite deep in many of the regions. It has been very difficult for communities, no matter who has been in government, to come to terms with some of the consequences of that.

I think you have displayed tremendous courage in, on the one hand, empathising with the concerns of people in rural Australia but at the same time always lifting their horizons towards the need for us to be part of the global scene. Never once did you drop the ball on populism. Never once did you give up arguing what we all know in the long term is right—that is, that if this nation is not competitive around the world it will not survive; that the future of this nation lies in it being competitive. The great things that have been done on both sides of politics over the last 20 years in the cause of a more competitive Australia have been those things done in the belief that we are part of a global community. I have always admired your commitment to those things and I have always admired your willingness to go out and fight for them.

I know that as the leader of the minority party in the coalition you sometimes have difficult decisions to explain to your constituencies. I am very conscious of how difficult the gun decision was for many people in the National Party. It was the right decision for Australia—unqualifiedly the right decision for Australia—and no member of my government has ever regretted that. I acknowledge the support received from the Australian Labor Party at the time. But it did cause difficulty in some of your ranks, just as some of the speculation over budget decisions relating to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme in 1996 caused difficulty. But you held the line, you argued the cause, you kept the faith on all occasions—sometimes against fierce opposition from your state colleagues who do not always see the endgame so far as the national interest is concerned. I think that tends to apply in all political parties at particular times.

I want to thank you, Tim, for your loyalty. I want to thank you and place on record my admiration for your being such a well-loved and well-respected Deputy Prime Minister. You are a very highly respected public figure in this country. Nowhere I go in Australia or around the world do I not find people who speak affectionately of Tim Fischer. I say that very sincerely and very genuinely. You are held in high esteem amongst foreign leaders, and you deserve all of that.

I know the stresses and strains that political life places on families, and I want to record my good wishes to Judy, to Harrison and to Dominic. I also know how much your family means to you, and I know that the welfare of your family has been uppermost in your mind in making the decision that you have made. In that, you have our great and undiminished respect, understanding and affection. It is this sort of decision that wins the full-blooded response and positive support of all Australians because you demonstrate that those personal things and those personal associations and relationships are, in the end, infinitely more important than any sort of glory, prestige, power or notoriety that might come our way, however fleetingly, in public life.

You have indicated to me and to the nation that you will be handing over as Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister of Australia on 20 July. As it happens, I will be going overseas next Monday for a period of 2½ weeks, and I think it is entirely appropriate and fitting that Tim end his ministerial career, his time as Leader of the National Party, as the Acting Prime Minister of our nation. I think it will give to many Australians in all walks of life, of all shades of political opinion, the opportunity to express to him as he goes around our country the tremendous esteem and regard in which he is held and the affection which he will always retain in the hearts of many. Thank you, mate, for your tremendous support and loyalty. I will miss you, but I will always remember what a tremendous political ally and warrior you have been.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—by leave—Tim, welcome to the club of ex-deputy prime ministers; you will have an honoured place in it, I can assure you. On behalf of my party, I would like to express our thanks and good regards for you, and our best regards to Judy and your family, in the decision that you have taken. You are one of the very genuinely loved people in this place. Even though I have been vigorously partisan on occasion, as with the release of our trade policy a couple of weeks ago, nevertheless I have to say that I am delighted to pay tribute to you and your avuncular style in the way in which you have conducted trade policy in the course of the last three years. We too on this side of the House appreciate your courage in a number of areas.

speech.para: The Prime Minister mentioned your standing up for the national interest in relation to the changes that were put in place on gun laws. We do comprehend, because in many ways the experiences that you had in struggling with an exceptionally difficult issue in your constituency we had to a much lesser degree in ours. Blokes are collectors—there are no two ways about it. We collect things, and one of the things that many of us collect are guns. It is responsible for a great deal of enjoyment and a great deal of personal satisfaction amongst many working-class men in this country who support both the Labor and the National parties in different areas of the nation—people who felt that they were most grievously put upon by those decisions.

It was in parts of Australia a difficult decision for us, but it was as nothing compared with the problems that you confronted in your political organisation at the time you took the decisions that you did. You stayed the course. It would have been an opportunity for you to differentiate yourself, or to allow large numbers of your members to differentiate themselves, from your coalition partners. There was no risk in that, none at all. We were going to vote for it. It would have passed this House very easily without the support of your National Party members. But you chose not that easy road out; you chose to lay your leadership on the line and persist in a course of action which was right for the country.

We have another area of deep appreciation for the role you have played, and that is the confrontation with those attitudes in this community that sought a racially selective approach to immigration and a racial outlook, both to internal affairs in relation to the Aboriginal community and to those migrants of a non-European background who had come to this country. At different points of time, it looked as though your political party was to be destroyed. You had an exceptionally difficult task of it to lead your political party in those circumstances where naturally—and I do not make this as a mocking point—there was flat panic in your ranks. There is, I think, a reward in honour for you for the role that you played then. That applies not just domestically but also to your role externally.

Frankly, in that period of time, the external reputation of Australia plummeted—absolutely plummeted. There is no sense in mincing words about that. That happens to be true. Because of your position, you were out there constantly having to argue the point that Australia was indeed a decent, tolerant society; that Australia was indeed an exemplar nation as far as both multiculturalism and multiracialism was concerned; and that an argument taking place did not eliminate those essential facts about Australian society. But the task of conveying that point was extraordinarily difficult. For a person who is, shall we say, `inventive' with his use of the English language, to have to carry that argument was indeed a challenge. I think you were obliged effectively on most occasions to carry it uniquely—and did you it very well.

You are also an excellent trade minister, being always well prepared. We had a disagreement over strategy with you in that regard. But any of us going overseas would always be there either slightly in advance of you or slightly in your wake. I do remember one occasion when we were jointly in India. A gentleman from the Indian political process asked me for an explanation. He had apparently been at a cricket match with you, and he asked me why the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia at 10 o'clock at night inside would be wearing a hat. I said that it was an ancient Australian religious custom and that you should not be mocked for it—and I notice that on occasions it seemed to be replicated in another way in India. We had our feelings too. But that Akubra has done you well in many countries on this planet, and you have defended the interests of this nation most effectively as you have gone through those various trade negotiations.

I do note that, when you have had the opportunity to speak on these occasions—occasions of a valedictory nature as opposed to the nature of a eulogy, because you will be around for a very long time to come, and you have probably taken a decision which will ensure that you stay around for a very long time to come for your family—you have never failed to recognise somebody's war service, if they have had it. You first came to our notice here when, as shadow minister for veterans' affairs, you were a most diligent exponent of the needs and concerns of Vietnam veterans, of which you are one. You gained a very affectionate place in our hearts at the time of your advocating their needs and concerns.

You have been 28 years in politics, and you are rightly proud of the fact that a boy from Boree Creek can enjoy such a lengthy period of service to the Australian people. Twenty-eight years is four times the average length of service in a parliament—and, indeed, that is no mean achievement.

I know you will go out with very great personal satisfaction about your career. You will go to the arms of a terrific family and a terrific wife. If I could use the word `idiosyncratic' again in this regard, one of your idiosyncrasies is that none of us expected to see you in that situation, as year on year we considered you a natural bachelor. When I was Minister for Defence—and I have had occasion to remark on this before—I used to struggle to provide you with new locations for Christmas dinner, as we sent peacekeepers around the world to prepare a table for you. Then all of a sudden you were missing, and that was because you then had a family. It is a terrific family indeed and you have a terrific wife.

You are going to be very much missed by us. I see you are going to hang around for a bit in parliament. I notice that your farewell trip is going to substantially feature rail within it. You will have an opportunity to look over a system which you have loved and advocated in this place for a lengthy period of time. But I also know that you will not be a stranger to this place. No matter how long you are actually formally a member of it, you love the various institutions you have served at different points of time and we would expect to see you around here for many years to come.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—by leave—In my capacity as Deputy Leader of the National Party, I feel it is appropriate to say a few words on behalf of the parliamentary National Party. Tim, there will be plenty of opportunities—indeed, I suspect a great number of them over the next little while—for us in the National Party to pay you tribute for the work that you have done for the party. But I know, too, that our colleagues here would want me to record in this place on this occasion our very deep appreciation of the work you have put in over the best part of 10 years in often very difficult circumstances—none more difficult than the time at which you became leader immediately following that very difficult—for us—1990 election.

speech.para: On behalf of the party, and I know on behalf of many others as well, can I record our profound appreciation of your dedication, your leadership and your sheer hard work over the best part of that 10 years. I have been beside you for 6½ years of that period. I say to all who are present and to those listening that the public image is right: in all of that time I have never known Tim to be anything other than utterly straight and utterly decent. The only thing that is more legendary than your decency, Tim, is your sheer energy. Can I say to you that we salute—to use a Timism, if I may—you and Judy very much, because there is no doubt that Australia is a better place for the service that you have rendered here.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—I observe that the Prime Minister has frequently said in this place—and everyone has endorsed his remarks—that the things that unite us as parliamentarians are much more significant than the things that divide us, and this afternoon we have seen a classic illustration of the truth of that remark.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Prime Minister, this House is united in saying thank you to you for the service you have rendered to the people of Australia and for the service you will go on rendering to the people of Farrer—thank you, we appreciate that. We are also united in extending to you, Judy and the family our very best wishes.
